subject: Cybersecurity
title: Password Hashing: How Passwords Are Stored
description: A short lesson to help you apply Password Hashing: How Passwords Are Stored.

hook.text: Good websites never store your actual password. They store a mathematical fingerprint that can't be reversed.

buildup.text: Hashing converts a password into a fixed-length string. The same input always produces the same hash, but you.

discovery.text: Salting adds random data before hashing, so even identical passwords produce different hashes in the database.

twist.text: LinkedIn stored passwords with unsalted SHA-1 in 2012. When breached, 6.5 million passwords were cracked in hours.

climax.text: Modern algorithms like bcrypt and Argon2 are deliberately slow, making brute-force attacks impractically expensive.

punchline.text: The best password storage is deliberately slow. Speed is the enemy.

quiz.question: Why is salting important in password hashing?
options: It makes passwords easier to remember
It ensures identical passwords produce different hashes, preventing rainbow table attacks
It speeds up the login process
